title: Spurs coach Gregg Popovich on Trump: 'It’s a strange land'
text:
Spurs coach Gregg Popovich on Trump: 'It’s a strange land' Gregg Doyel , gregg.doyel@indystar.com Published 6:46 p.m. ET Feb. 13, 2017 | Updated 8 hours ago Feb 8, 2017; Philadelphia, PA, USA; San Antonio Spurs head coach Gregg Popovich talks with guard Tony Parker (9) during a break in action against the Philadelphia 76ers in the first quarter at Wells Fargo Center. Mandatory Credit: Bill Streicher-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Bill Streicher, Bill Streicher-USA TODAY Sports) 173 CONNECT 13 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
INDIANAPOLIS – Three months after launching into a six-minute diatribe about the election of President Donald Trump, San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich on Monday called “unacceptable and really disgusting” Trump’s “willingness to do whatever’s necessary to get elected.” 
Speaking outside the Spurs locker room about 75 minutes before tipoff at Bankers Life Fieldhouse against the Indiana Pacers, Popovich said Trump’s presidency has had the following effect on him: 
“Some days I feel like we’ve been invaded by another power and taken over (by people) who don’t feel the same,” Popovich said. “It’s a strange land.” 
Popovich’s nearly four-minute political commentary was triggered by a question regarding how his background – he was born and raised in East Chicago and played pickup basketball on the outdoor courts of Gary – affected his worldview. 
“I also grew up with white people, too,” Popovich mused. “Up in Merrillville.” 
Then he turned serious, digging into Trump’s first month in office and making a vague reference to Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, Judge Neil M. Gorsuch . 
Popovich’s comments Monday, in full: 
“Sometimes when life moves along, you’re presented with situations where you just find it necessary to speak,” he said, “because so many people seem to be afraid to, or are unwilling to face it and (instead) let things go and just worry about their own situation. Most of those people have had opportunities that the majority have not. 
“So I think it’s important for people who’ve had opportunity to make sure that other people with opportunity know that they were very, very, very fortunate. That could have been having a couple of parents, where you were born, what your skin color is, what country you were born in. It’s all chance. You didn’t do that. You get no credit for that, for getting those opportunities. People have an easy time forgetting that. 
“The situation now, I find a lot of people are in charge – or will be in charge shortly when they’re nominated – have very little clue about what many, many people have to go through to live in this world. Some days I feel like we’ve been invaded by another power and taken over (by people) who don’t feel the same. It’s a strange land.” 
Popovich was asked a follow-up: What does he think of all the athletes and coaches who don’t speak up? 
“I don’t worry too much,” he said. “Somebody (could) say: ‘Go coach your basketball team, go do this, go say you’re sorry, go run the football,’ whatever it might be. I think it’s important that we don’t forget. 
“We all hope that President Trump is successful. We hope he does some good things for everybody. But he didn’t start the presidency by mollifying any groups that he disparaged. He didn’t say anything (conciliatory toward) black people, or Mexican people, Hispanic people, LGBT people, handicapped people. Acted like it never happened. 
“So that willingness to do whatever’s necessary to get elected, to say and act the way he did, I thought was unacceptable and really disgusting. So I said it. And I think that even people who voted for him can see that, but for some reason they feel they can afford to forget about it. 
“(Trump’s) personality and his inability to get over himself and form his words and his decisions – that’s what scares me.” 
The next question asked of Popovich: Will Jonathan Simmons be available tonight? 
"Yes," Popovich said.
